Vaux's ambitious building was not well received; the building's [[Gothic Revival|High Victorian Gothic]] style being considered already dated prior to completion, and the president of the Met termed the project "a mistake".{{cite journal |url=http://www.newyorker.com/talk/2008/12/01/081201ta_talk_halford?printable=true |title=At the Museums: Four Eyes |last=Halford |first=Macy |date=December 1, 2008 |work=[[The New Yorker]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218053644/https://www.newyorker.com/talk/2008/12/01/081201ta_talk_halford?printable=true |archivedate=December 18, 2008 |df= }} Within 20 years, a new architectural plan engulfing the Vaux building was already being executed. Since that time, many additions have been made including the distinctive [[Beaux-Arts architecture|Beaux-Arts]] Fifth Avenue facade, Great Hall, and Grand Stairway. These were designed by architect and Met trustee [[Richard Morris Hunt]], but completed by his son, [[Richard Howland Hunt]] in 1902 after his father's death.Gross, Michael, ''Rogues' Gallery, The Secret History of the Moguls and the Money That Made the Metropolitan Museum'', Broadway Books, New York, 2009, p. 75. The [[architectural sculpture]] on the facade is by [[Karl Bitter]].Schevill, Ferdinand, 'Karl Bitter: A Biography", The University of Chicago Press, Chicago, Illinois, 1917 p. ix [[File:View of Central Park from The Metropolitan Museum of Art (425424361).jpg|thumb|Northern view of Central Park through the glass wall of the [[Temple of Dendur]] room]] The wings that completed the Fifth Avenue facade in the 1910s were designed by the firm of [[McKim, Mead & White]]. The modernistic glass sides and rear of the museum are the work of [[Roche-Dinkeloo]]. [[Kevin Roche]] has been the architect for the master plan and expansion of the museum for the past 42 years. He is responsible for designing all of its new wings and renovations including but not limited to the American Wing, Greek and Roman Court, and recently opened Islamic Wing.The Metropolitan Museum of Art Bulletin (Summer 1995) As of 2010, the Met measures almost {{convert|1/4|mi|m|adj=on}} long and with more than {{convert|2000000|ft2|m2}} of floor space, more than 20 times the size of the original 1880 building.{{cite web |url=http://www.humanitiesweb.org/human.php?s=g&p=a&a=i&ID=1138 |title=The Metropolitan Museum of Art at HumanitiesWeb |publisher=Humanitiesweb.org |date=2012-01-13 |accessdate=2012-06-11 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120601220656/http://www.humanitiesweb.org/human.php?s=g |archivedate=2012-06-01 |df= }} The museum building is an accretion of over 20 structures, most of which are not visible from the exterior. The City of New York owns the museum building and contributes utilities, heat, and some of the cost of guardianship. The Charles Engelhard Court of the American Wing features the facade of the Branch Bank of the United States, a Wall Street bank that was facing demolition in 1913.{{cite news|last=Vogel|first=Carol|title=The Met Offers a New Look at Americana|newspaper=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/05/arts/design/05met.html|date=May 4, 2009|accessdate=November 25, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161126194402/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/05/arts/design/05met.html|archivedate=November 26, 2016|df=}}{{cite web|last=Heckscher|first=Morrison H.|title=The Metropolitan Museum of Art: An Architectural History|publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art|page=54|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/pubs/bulletins/1/pdf/3259465.pdf.bannered.pdf|date=Summer 1995|accessdate=November 25, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202002010/http://www.metmuseum.org/pubs/bulletins/1/pdf/3259465.pdf.bannered.pdf|archivedate=February 2, 2017|df=}} The museum's main building was designated a [[National Historic Landmark]] in 1986, recognizing both its monumental architecture, and its importance as a cultural institution.{{cite web|url={{NHLS url|86003556}}|title=NHL nomination for Metropolitan Museum of Art|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2017-12-29}} === Roof garden === [[File:Memantra pic.JPG|thumb|upright|left|Memantra by [[Frank Stella]] on exhibit in the roof garden.]] The [[Iris Cantor|Iris]] and [[B. Gerald Cantor]] Roof Garden is located on the roof near the southwestern corner of the museum. The garden's cafe and bar is a popular museum spot during the mild-weathered months, especially on Friday and Saturday evenings when large crowds can lead to long lines at the elevators. The roof garden offers views of [[Central Park]] and the Manhattan skyline.{{cite book| last=Nash| first=Eric Peter| title=New York's 50 Best Secret Architectural Treasures| publisher=City & Co.| year=1996| location=New York| isbn=978-1-885492-31-9}}{{cite book| last=Baron| first=James| author2=[[Anna Quindlen]]| title=The New York Times Book of New York: 549 Stories of the People, the Events, and the Life of the City—Past and Present| publisher=[[Black Dog Publishing]]| year=2009| location=London| isbn=978-1-57912-801-2}} The garden is the gift of philanthropists Iris and B. Gerald Cantor, founder and chairman of [[Security (finance)|securities]] firm [[Cantor Fitzgerald]].{{cite web |url=http://www.cantorfoundation.org/Bios/gerald.html |title=Biography of B. Gerald Cantor |publisher=www.cantorfoundation.org |accessdate=June 30, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110621215344/http://www.cantorfoundation.org/Bios/gerald.html |archivedate=June 21, 2011 |df= }} The garden was opened to the public on August 1, 1987.{{cite news| title=New Roof Garden at Metropolitan Museum| newspaper=The New York Times| date=June 4, 1987| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/04/nyregion/new-roof-garden-at-metropolitan-museum.html?pagewanted=1| accessdate=June 30, 2010| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150111051924/http://www.nytimes.com/1987/06/04/nyregion/new-roof-garden-at-metropolitan-museum.html?pagewanted=1| archivedate=January 11, 2015| df=}} Every summer since 1998 the roof garden has hosted a single-artist exhibition. The artists have been: [[Ellsworth Kelly]] (1998), [[Magdalena Abakanowicz]] (1999), [[David Smith (sculptor)|David Smith]] (2000), [[Joel Shapiro]] (2001), [[Claes Oldenburg]] and [[Coosje van Bruggen]] (2002), [[Roy Lichtenstein]] (2003), [[Andy Goldsworthy]] (2004), [[Sol LeWitt]] (2005), [[Cai Guo-Qiang]] (2006), [[Frank Stella]] (2007), [[Jeff Koons]] (2008), [[Roxy Paine]] (2009) and [[Big Bambú]] by [[Doug and Mike Starn]] (2010).{{cite press release| title=Doug and Mike Starn Create Monumental Sculpture for Metropolitan Museum's 2010 Roof Garden Installation; Big Bambú to Open April 27 April 27– October 31, 2010 (weather permitting)| publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art| date=April 27, 2010| url=http://www.artinfo.com/galleryguide/19639/6185/124295/the-metropolitan-museum-of-art-new-york/exhibition/big-bambu/press_release/| accessdate=June 30, 2010| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100703221243/http://www.artinfo.com/galleryguide/19639/6185/124295/the-metropolitan-museum-of-art-new-york/exhibition/big-bambu/press_release/| archivedate=July 3, 2010| df=}} The roof garden has views of the [[Manhattan Island|Manhattan]] skyline from a vantage point high above Central Park.{{cite news| last=Louie| first=Elaine| title=A Sip and a View, Without the Grit| newspaper=The New York Times| date=July 17, 1996| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/17/garden/a-sip-and-a-view-without-the-grit.html| accessdate=June 30, 2010| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150111051737/http://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/17/garden/a-sip-and-a-view-without-the-grit.html| archivedate=January 11, 2015| df=}} The views have been described as "the best in Manhattan."{{cite news| last=Miller| first=Lori| title=Met's Garden: Where Views Enhance Art| newspaper=The New York Times| date=August 2, 1987| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/02/nyregion/met-s-garden-where-views-enhance-art.html?pagewanted=1| accessdate=June 30, 2010| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150111051740/http://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/02/nyregion/met-s-garden-where-views-enhance-art.html?pagewanted=1| archivedate=January 11, 2015| df=}} [[Art critic]]s have been known to complain that the view "distracts" from the art on exhibition.{{cite news| title=Museum and Gallery Listings| newspaper=The New York Times| date=May 16, 2008| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/16/arts/design/16wart.html?ref=design| accessdate=June 30, 2010| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150904034514/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/16/arts/design/16wart.html?ref=design| archivedate=September 4, 2015| df=}} ''New York Times'' art critic [[Ken Johnson (art critic)|Ken Johnson]] complains that the "breathtaking, panoramic views of Central Park and the Manhattan skyline" creates "an inhospitable site for sculpture" that "discourages careful, contemplative looking."{{cite news| last=Johnson| first=Ken| title=Art Review, A Panoramic Backdrop for Meaning and Mischief| newspaper=The New York Times| date=April 22, 2008| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/22/arts/design/22koon.html| accessdate=June 30, 2010| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110925193352/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/22/arts/design/22koon.html| archivedate=September 25, 2011| df=}} Writer [[Mindy Aloff]] describes the roof garden as "the loveliest airborne space I know of in New York."{{cite news| last=Aloff| first=Mindy| title=Where to Cool Both Soul and Heels| newspaper=The New York Times| date=August 22, 1997| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/22/arts/where-to-cool-both-soul-and-heels.html?pagewanted=all| accessdate=June 30, 2010| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150111051926/http://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/22/arts/where-to-cool-both-soul-and-heels.html?pagewanted=all| archivedate=January 11, 2015| df=}} The cafe and bar in this garden are considered romantic by many.{{cite book| last=Bykofsky| first=Sheree| author2=Arthur Schwart| title=The 52 Most Romantic Dates in and Around New York City| publisher=Adams Media| year=2001| location=Avon, Massachusetts| page=63| isbn=978-1-58062-462-6}}{{cite journal| last=Bennett| first=Bruce| title=Nightlife: The Iris and B. Gerald Cantor Roof Garden| work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]| url=http://nymag.com/listings/bar/iris-and-b-gerald-cantor-roof-garden/| accessdate=June 30, 2010| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100916063122/http://nymag.com/listings/bar/iris-and-b-gerald-cantor-roof-garden/| archivedate=September 16, 2010| df=}} == Management == === Governance === Although the City of New York owns the museum building and contributes utilities, heat, and some of the cost of guardianship, the collections are owned by a private corporation of fellows and benefactors which totals about 950 persons. The museum is governed by a board of trustees of 41 elected members, several officials of the City of New York, and persons honored as trustees by the museum. The current chairman of the board, [[Daniel Brodsky]] was elected in 2011. Other notable trustees include [[Anna Wintour]], [[Richard Chilton]], [[Hughes Hubbard & Reed|Candace Beinecke]], [[Alejandro Santo Domingo]]{{cite web| url=http://www.metmuseum.org/about-the-museum/annual-reports/~/media/924DCB0D4562488A8DC818F4515912BE.pdf| title=Annual Report: Board of Trustees| date=November 1, 2014| publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141217062337/http://www.metmuseum.org/about-the-museum/annual-reports/~/media/924DCB0D4562488A8DC818F4515912BE.pdf| archivedate=December 17, 2014| df=}} as well as Mayor [[Bill de Blasio]] and his appointee [[Ken Sunshine]].{{cite news| first=Emily| last=Smith| date=September 13, 2014| url=http://pagesix.com/2014/09/13/ken-sunshine-joins-the-mets-board-of-trustees/| title=Ken Sunshine Joins the Met's Board of Trustees| work=New York Post| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141115172725/http://pagesix.com/2014/09/13/ken-sunshine-joins-the-mets-board-of-trustees/| archivedate=November 15, 2014| df=}} On March 10, 2015, the board of trustees chose [[Daniel Weiss (art historian)|Daniel Weiss]], then president of [[Haverford College]], to be the current president and chief operating officer of the Met, replacing Emily K. Rafferty, who served in that role for a decade.{{cite news| last1=Kennedy| first1=Randy| title=Metropolitan Museum of Art Names New President: Daniel Weiss| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/11/arts/design/daniel-h-weiss-of-haverford-expected-to-be-metropolitan-museums-new-president.html?_r=0| accessdate=13 March 2015| work=The New York Times| date=10 March 2015| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403100746/http://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/11/arts/design/daniel-h-weiss-of-haverford-expected-to-be-metropolitan-museums-new-president.html?_r=0| archivedate=3 April 2015| df=}} The search for a new director and CEO for the Museum was announced on February 28, 2017 and assigned to be conducted by the human resources firm Phillips Oppenheim following the departure of Thomas Campbell as the Met's director and previous CEO on June 30, 2017. The activities of Board of Trustees is organized and based upon the activities of the individual trustees and their various committees as of 2016. The several committees of the Board of Trustees include the committees listed as Nominating, Executive, Acquisitions, Finance, Investment, Legal, Education, Audit, Employee Benefits, External Affairs, Merchandising, Membership, Building, Technology and The Fund for the Met. The list of elective trustees of the Met for 2016–2017 included [[Jeffrey W. Greenberg]], [[Sherman Fairchild Foundation|Bonnie B. Himmelman]], and [[Andrew Solomon]]. === Finances === As of 2017, the museum's endowment as administered by the museum's new investment officer Lauren Meserve is $3.1 billion USD which provides much of the income for operations while admissions account for only 13 percent of revenue as of fiscal 2016."Metropolitan Museum of Art Names Lauren A. Meserve Senior Vice President and Chief Investment Officer", BY Alex Greenberger, Artnews Journal, October 18, 2017. {{cite web |url=http://www.artnews.com/2017/10/18/metropolitan-museum-of-art-names-lauren-a-meserve-senior-vice-president-and-chief-investment-officer/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-10-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171019055150/http://www.artnews.com/2017/10/18/metropolitan-museum-of-art-names-lauren-a-meserve-senior-vice-president-and-chief-investment-officer/ |archivedate=2017-10-19 |df= }}.{{cite web| title=Annual Report for the Year 2009–2010| publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art| date=November 9, 2010| url=http://www.metmuseum.org/~/media/Files/About/Annual%20Reports/2009_2010/2010_Annual_Report.pdf| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140713015244/http://metmuseum.org/~/media/Files/About/Annual%20Reports/2009_2010/2010_Annual_Report.pdf| archivedate=July 13, 2014| df=}}Katchka, Boris (2017). "What Broke the Met?", April 17, 2017, ''New York'' magazine, pp44-50. The 2009–10 operating budget was $221 million. The museum admission price as of March 2018 is $25 for out-of-state and foreign visitors, while New York state residents can [[Pay what you want|pay what they wish]] to enter. Although subject to re-assessment,{{cite web | last=Pogrebin | first=Robin | title=Visit to the Met Could Cost You, if You Don't Live in New York | website=The New York Times | date=2017-04-26 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/26/arts/design/met-museum-in-quiet-talks-with-city-weighs-an-admission-fee.html | access-date=2018-01-12 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113035506/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/26/arts/design/met-museum-in-quiet-talks-with-city-weighs-an-admission-fee.html | archivedate=2018-01-13 | df= }} a 1970 agreement between the museum and the city of New York requires New York state visitors to pay at least a nominal amount; a penny is acceptable.{{cite news|title=NYC art museum accused of duping visitors on admission fees|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2013/03/25/nyc-art-museum-accused-duping-visitors-on-admission-fees/|date=25 March 2013|publisher=Associated Press/Fox News|accessdate=26 March 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130326021118/http://www.foxnews.com/us/2013/03/25/nyc-art-museum-accused-duping-visitors-on-admission-fees/|archivedate=26 March 2013|df=}} The Met's finance committee is led by [[Hamilton E. James]] of [[The Blackstone Group]], who is also one of the board members at the Met. The Met is reported to have an Aaa [[Bond credit rating|credit rating]], the highest such rating possible. This was last affirmed by [[Moody's]] in 2015.{{Cite news|url=https://www.moodys.com/research/Moodys-assigns-Aaa-to-Metropolitan-Museum-of-Arts-NY-250M--PR_316776|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171019004655/https://www.moodys.com/research/Moodys-assigns-Aaa-to-Metropolitan-Museum-of-Arts-NY-250M--PR_316776|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2017-10-19|title=Moody's assigns Aaa to Metropolitan Museum of Art's (NY) $250M Series 2015 bonds; outlook stable|last=|first=|date=2015-01-20|work=[[Moody's]]|access-date=2017-05-06}} ==== 2015–2018 setbacks ==== In September 2016, the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' first reported financial set-backs at the museum related to servicing its outstanding debts and associated cut-backs in staffing at the museum, with the goal of trying to balance its budget by fiscal year 2018.Jennifer Smith, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/metropolitan-museum-of-art-cuts-staff-1475072125 "Metropolitan Museum of Art Cuts Staff"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170329045832/https://www.wsj.com/articles/metropolitan-museum-of-art-cuts-staff-1475072125 |date=2017-03-29 }}, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', September 28, 2016. According to the Met's annual tax filing for fiscal year 2016, several top executives had received disproportionately high compensation, often exceeding 1M USD per annum with over 100K USD bonuses per annum.{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/met-execs-awarded-bonus-and-raises-894431|title=Met Execs Got Hefty Bonuses Amid Rising Deficit|last=Kinsella|first=Eileen|date=2017-03-16|work=artnet News|access-date=2017-05-06|language=en-US|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170325223837/https://news.artnet.com/art-world/met-execs-awarded-bonus-and-raises-894431|archivedate=2017-03-25|df=}} In April 2017, the ''New York Times'' reported that the Met's annual debt was approaching $40 million, in addition to an outstanding museum bond for $250 million. This resulted in the indefinite postponement of a planned $600 million architectural expansion of the exhibition space for the museum's modern art collection as well as started a general discussion over the Met's [[human resources management]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/02/arts/design/met-museum-campbell-resignation-brodsky-coburn.html|title=A Hushed Departure at the Met Museum Reveals Entrenched Management Culture|last=Pogrebin|first=Robin|date=2017-04-02|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-05-06|issn=0362-4331|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170414145243/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/02/arts/design/met-museum-campbell-resignation-brodsky-coburn.html|archivedate=2017-04-14|df=}} The current chairman of the board at the Met elected in 2011, [[Real Estate Board of New York|Daniel Brodsky]],{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/11/arts/design/daniel-brodsky-is-voted-chairman-of-metropolitan-museum.html|title=Daniel Brodsky is Voted Chairman of the Metropolitan Museum of Art|last=Taylor|first=Kate|date=May 5, 2011|work=The New York Times|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170314074207/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/11/arts/design/daniel-brodsky-is-voted-chairman-of-metropolitan-museum.html|archivedate=March 14, 2017|df=}} stated in response to the ''Times'' reports that he "looked forward to working with my administrative and board colleagues to support a climate of candor, transparency, accountability and mutual respect." In January 2018, Daniel Weiss as president of the museum stated that a downsized version of the original $600 million architectural expansion might be reconsidered as early as 2020 at a reduction to the $450 million level. Brodsky, the Chairman of the Met, stated that after the 2017 financial setbacks, the Director position would be appointed separately from the position of CEO. Following a commissioned report from the [[Boston Consulting Group]], the current interim CEO, president, and [[Chief Operating Officer|COO]] of the Met, [[Daniel Weiss (art historian)|Daniel Weiss]], said that the Met's 2015–2017 financial setbacks were caused by "slowing revenue, rising costs, and too many projects at once." Weiss was further reported as having hired Will Manzer, formerly an executive at [[Perry Ellis (brand)|Perry Ellis]], to help re-invigorate recently declining revenues at the museum.{{Cite news|url=http://www.vulture.com/2017/04/what-broke-the-met-museum.html|title=With Rumors, Scandal, and a Record Budget Shortfall, What Broke the Met?|last=Kachka|first=Boris|date=April 16, 2017|work=Vulture|access-date=2017-05-06|publisher=[[New York (magazine)|New York Magazine]]|pages=44–50|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170501102836/http://www.vulture.com/2017/04/what-broke-the-met-museum.html|archivedate=May 1, 2017|df=}} On April 26, Weiss stated that the budget shortfall of $15 million might require a re-assessment and increase in the museum's current admission payment policy. Weiss added that there remained concerns for a sustainable fiscal model for the Met in which city officials "have a right to a clear understanding of how we would be engaging the public, how we balance access with sustainability."{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/26/arts/design/met-museum-in-quiet-talks-with-city-weighs-an-admission-fee.html|title=Visit to the Met Could Cost You, if You Don't Live in New York|last=Pogrebin|first=Robin|date=2017-04-26|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-05-06|issn=0362-4331|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170506225037/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/26/arts/design/met-museum-in-quiet-talks-with-city-weighs-an-admission-fee.html|archivedate=2017-05-06|df=}} In May 2017, the Met filed formal proposal to attempt to charge admission fees to out-of-state visitors. [[Robin Pogrebin]], writing for the ''Times,'' reported that the request for out-of-state admissions would call for the re-legislation of the New York State 1893 Act which requires that the museum's collections "shall be kept open and accessible to the public free of all charge throughout the year," and any unlegislated changes would be subject to challenge by the New York State attorney general, [[Eric Schneiderman]], or one of the tristate counselors, [[Christopher Porrino]] or [[George Jepsen]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/05/arts/design/the-metropolitcan-museum-of-art-admission-fees-tickets-de-blasio.html|title=The Met Files a Formal Proposal to Charge Admission to Out-of-State Visitors|last=Pogrebin|first=Robin|date=2017-05-05|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-05-06|issn=0362-4331|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170506050919/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/05/arts/design/the-metropolitcan-museum-of-art-admission-fees-tickets-de-blasio.html|archivedate=2017-05-06|df=}} In January 2018, Pogrebin writing for ''The New York Times'' reported that amid continuing reverbations from "a period of financial turbulence and leadership turmoil" that the museum president Daniel Weiss had announced that the museum would rescind its century old policy of free admission to the museum and begin charging $25 for out-of-state visitors starting in March 2018. Pogrebin stated that although the museum had made progress in decreasing its deficit from forty million dollars to ten million dollars, that an adverse decision from the City of New York to curtail funding for the Met's operating costs by as much as eight million dollars "for security and building staff" caused Weiss to announce the change in admissions policy. Weiss indicated that the new policy would be estimated to increase revue from the current $43 million it receives from admissions to an enhanced revenue stream as high as $49 million USD. === Attendance === For the fiscal year 2017 which ended on June 30, the museum was reported as having 7 million visitors during the past year, where "37 percent of these were international visitors, while 30 percent came from New York's five boroughs."Staff authors (July 12, 2017), [https://news.artnet.com/art-world/art-industry-news-july-12-1020134 The Met Museum Boasts Record Attendance Numbers] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180112214754/https://news.artnet.com/art-world/art-industry-news-july-12-1020134 |date=2018-01-12 }} ''ArtNet News''. Previously in 2016, the museum set a record for attendance, attracting 6.7 million visitors—the highest number since the museum began tracking admissions.{{cite web | last=Pogrebin | first=Robin | title=The Metropolitan Museum of Art Announces Record Attendance | website=The New York Times | date=2016-08-05 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/05/arts/design/the-metropolitan-museum-of-art-announces-record-attendance.html | access-date=2018-01-12 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180112215040/https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/05/arts/design/the-metropolitan-museum-of-art-announces-record-attendance.html | archivedate=2018-01-12 | df= }} Forty percent of the Met's visitors in fiscal year 2016 came from New York City and the tristate area; 41 percent from 190 countries besides the United States. In 2017, the attendance figures indicated seven million annual visitors with 63% of the visitors arriving from outside of New York State. [[Roberta Smith]] writing for ''The New York Times'' in September 2017 voiced growing public concern that proposed increases in admissions costs would have an adverse effect upon attendance statistics at the museum. Smith referred to the public perception that such costs would appear "greedy and inapproriate" because "The museum already gets around $39 million a year from its gate -- equal to the entire annual budget of the Brooklyn Museum."Smith, Roberta. "The Fall's Most Fascinating Art Show." ''The New York Times.'' 4 September 2017. {{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/04/arts/design/director-metropolitan-museum-search-daniel-weiss.html?rref=collection%2Ftimestopic%2FMetropolitan%20Museum%20of%20Art&action=click&contentCollection=timestopics®ion=stream&module=stream_unit&version=latest&contentPlacement=2&pgtype=collection |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-09-05 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170905235645/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/04/arts/design/director-metropolitan-museum-search-daniel-weiss.html?rref=collection%2Ftimestopic%2FMetropolitan%20Museum%20of%20Art&action=click&contentCollection=timestopics®ion=stream&module=stream_unit&version=latest&contentPlacement=2&pgtype=collection |archivedate=2017-09-05 |df= }} Smith's article continued to report the negative response of local communities in the tristate area surrounding the museum which was previously introduced in a series of articles by [[Robin Pogrebin]] written during the 2016-2017 fiscal year at the museum which criticized speculative suggestions among current administrators at the museum that an added revenue stream could be pursued by the museum by rescinding existing museum policy since 1893 allowing for free public access to the museum. In January 2018, museum president Daniel Weiss announced that the century-old policy of free museum admission would be replaced. Effective March 2018, the vast majority of visitors who do not live in New York State will have to pay $25 to enter the museum. The City of New York has reduced funding at the Metropolitan as part of Mayor De Blasio's political effort to increase artistic diversity. They made an agreement to allow the fees in exchange for less funding which the city pledged to use at alternate facilities and promote diversity.{{cite web | last=Pogrebin | first=Robin | title=De Blasio, With 'Cultural Plan,' Proposes Linking Money to Diversity | website=The New York Times | date=2017-05-08 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/19/arts/design/new-york-cultural-plan-museums.html | access-date=2018-01-12 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180111062426/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/19/arts/design/new-york-cultural-plan-museums.html | archivedate=2018-01-11 | df= }} Both Holland Carter and [[Roberta Smith]] of ''The New York Times'' have argued in response to Weiss's decision to rescind the previous free admission policy as lacking in responsible fiscal planning. They stated that a recent $65 million expenditure for renovating fountains seemed to be a poor allocation of the limited available funding. Smith added, "Those new awful Darth Vaderish fountains take huge chunks out of the plaza and disrupt movement," as an indication of the misuse of funds.Robert Smith and Holland Carter. "The Met Should Be Open to All. The New Pay Policy Is a Mistake." Jan. 4, 2018, The New York Times. {{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/04/arts/design/the-met-should-be-open-to-all-the-new-pay-policy-is-a-mistake.html?_r=0 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2018-01-08 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180109121957/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/04/arts/design/the-met-should-be-open-to-all-the-new-pay-policy-is-a-mistake.html?_r=0 |archivedate=2018-01-09 |df= }}. Further criticism of Weiss's proposal was voiced internationally when ''The Guardian'' summarized the backlash from the Weiss proposal for raising the admissions fees. It stated, "Some critics are outraged. The past week has seen a ''New York Times'' piece titled "The New Pay Policy Is a Mistake", while Jezebel's Aimée Lutkin claimed "The Met Should Be Fucking Free". ''The New York Post'' writes that the museum has never had the right to charge admission and Alexandra Schwartz in the ''New Yorker'' says the new policy diminishes New York City".Nadja Sayej. ''The Guardian''. "'Museums should be accessible': the backlash to the Met's new pricing policy". January 8, 2018. {{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2018/jan/08/met-museum-new-pricing-policy-backlash |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2018-01-09 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180109211513/https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2018/jan/08/met-museum-new-pricing-policy-backlash |archivedate=2018-01-09 |df= }}. == Acquisitions and deaccessioning == {{See also|Looted art}} The Metropolitan Museum of Art spent $39 million to acquire art for the fiscal year ending in June 2012.Robin Pogrebin (July 22, 2013), [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/23/arts/design/qatar-uses-its-riches-to-buy-art-treasures.html "Qatar Uses Its Riches to Buy Art Treasures"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170213115617/http://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/23/arts/design/qatar-uses-its-riches-to-buy-art-treasures.html |date=2017-02-13 }}, ''[[The New York Times]]''. At the same time, the museum is required to list in its annual report the total cash proceeds from art sales each year and to itemize any deaccessioned objects valued at more than $50,000 each. It must also sell those pieces at auction and provide advance public notice of a work being sold if it has been on view in the last ten years. These rules were imposed by the [[New York State Attorney General]] in 1972.{{cite news| first=Robin| last=Pogrebin| date=January 26, 2011| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/27/arts/design/27sell.html| title=The Permanent Collection May Not Be So Permanent| work=The New York Times| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151025181727/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/27/arts/design/27sell.html| archivedate=October 25, 2015| df=}} During the 1970s, under the directorship of [[Thomas Hoving]], the Met revised its [[deaccessioning (museum)|deaccessioning]] policy. Under the new policy, the Met set its sights on acquiring "world-class" pieces, regularly funding the purchases by selling mid- to high-value items from its collection. Though the Met had always sold duplicate or minor items from its collection to fund the acquisition of new pieces, the Met's new policy was significantly more aggressive and wide-ranging than before, and allowed the deaccessioning of items with higher values which would normally have precluded their sale. The new policy provoked a great deal of criticism (in particular, from ''[[The New York Times]]'') but had its intended effect. Many of the items then purchased with funds generated by the more liberal deaccessioning policy are now considered the "stars" of the Met's collection, including [[Diego Velázquez]]'s ''[[Portrait of Juan de Pareja]]'' and the [[Euphronios krater]] depicting the death of [[Sarpedon]] (which has since been repatriated to the Republic of Italy). In the years since the Met began its new deaccessioning policy, other museums have begun to emulate it with aggressive deaccessioning programs of their own.{{cite news| first=James| last=Bone| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,11069-1851184,00.html |title=Brimful museums put art under the hammer| work=[[The Times]]| date=October 31, 2005| accessdate=2012-06-11| location=London}} The Met has continued the policy in recent years, selling such valuable pieces as [[Edward Steichen]]'s 1904 photograph ''[[The Pond-Moonlight]]'' (of which another copy was already in the Met's collection) for a record price of $2.9 million.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/4715106.stm| title=Rare photo sets $2.9m sales record| work=[[BBC News]]| date=2006-02-15| accessdate=2013-02-18| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090131215727/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/4715106.stm| archivedate=2009-01-31| df=}} One of the most serious challenges to the Metropolitan Museum's reputation has been a series of allegations and lawsuits about its status as an institutional buyer of looted and stolen antiquities. Since the 1990s the Met has been the subject of numerous investigative reports and books critical of the Met's ''laissez-faire'' attitude to acquisition.Peter Watson, Cecilia Todeschini (2007), [https://books.google.com/books?id=jlcPcCuicKQC&q=Morgantina%20Met%20OR%20Metropolitan ''The Medici Conspiracy: The Illicit Journey of Looted Antiquities from Italy's Tomb Raiders to the World's Greatest Museums''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170215012119/https://books.google.com/books?id=jlcPcCuicKQC&q=Morgantina%20Met%20OR%20Metropolitan |date=2017-02-15 }}Vernon Silver, ''The Lost Chalice: The Epic Hunt for a Priceless Masterpiece''. Harper Collins Books, 2009. {{ISBN|978-0-06-188296-8}} The Met has lost several major lawsuits, notably against the governments of Italy and Turkey, who successfully sought the repatriation of hundreds of ancient Mediterranean and Middle Eastern antiquities, with a total value in the hundreds of millions of dollars. == Selected objects == File:Standing male worshiper MET DT850.jpg|Standing male worshiper, Mesopotamian, 2750-2600 BC(?) revision.text:
[[File:Museum of Anthropology at UBC 11.JPG|thumb|The [[Museum of Anthropology at UBC|Museum of Anthropology]] at [[University of British Columbia|UBC]]. ]] '''Museology''' or '''museum studies''' is the study of [[museum]]s. It explores the history of museums and their role in society, as well as the activities they engage in, including [[Curator|curating]], [[Conservation-restoration of cultural heritage|preservation]], public programming, and [[Museum education|education]].
== Terminology == The words that are used to describe the study of museums vary depending on language and geography. For example, while “museology” is becoming more prevalent in English, it is most commonly used to refer to the study of museums in French (muséologie), Spanish (museología), German (Museologie), Italian (museologia), and Portuguese (museologia) – while English speakers more often use the term “museum studies” to refer to that same field of study. When referring to the day-to-day operations of museums, other European languages typically use derivatives of the [[Latin]] “museographia” (French: muséographie, Spanish: museografía, German: Museographie, Italian: museografia, Portuguese: museografia), while English speakers typically use the term “museum practice” or “operational museology”<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://icom.museum/fileadmin/user_upload/pdf/Key_Concepts_of_Museology/Museologie_Anglais_BD.pdf|title=Key Concepts of Museology|last=International Council of Museums|first=|date=2009|website=icom.museum/fileadmin/user_upload/pdf/Key_Concepts_of_Museology/Museologie_Anglais_BD.pdf|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==Development of the field == The development of museology in Europe coincided with the emergence of early [[Collecting#History|collectors]] and [[Cabinet of curiosities|cabinets of curiosity]] in the 16th, 17th, and 18th centuries. In particular, during [[Age of Enlightenment|The Age of Enlightenment]] anthropologists, naturalists, and hobbyist collectors encouraged the growth of public museums that displayed [[Natural history museum|natural history]] and ethnographic objects and art in North America and Europe. In the 18th and 19th centuries, European powers’ [[colonization]] of overseas lands was accompanied by the development of the disciplines of natural history and ethnography, and the rise of private and institutional collection building. In many cases museums became the holding places for collections that were acquired through colonial conquests, which positioned museums as key institutions in [[Western Europe]]an [[Western European colonialism and colonization|colonial projects]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Ecomuseums: A Sense of Place|last=Davis|first=Peter|publisher=Continuum International Publishing: London.|year=2011|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>
In the 19th century, European museology was focused on framing museums as institutions that would educate and “civilize” the general public. Museums typically served nationalist interests, and their primary purpose was often to celebrate the state, country, or colonial power. Though [[World's fair|World’s Fairs]], such as [[The Great Exhibition|The Great Exhibition of 1851]] in London or the [[World's Columbian Exposition|Chicago World’s Fair]], were temporary, they were some of the first examples of large-scale exhibition spaces dedicated to nationalist agendas; both Britain and America wanted to assert themselves as international leaders in science and industry.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Civilization in the West|last=Kishlansky|first=M.|last2=Geary|first2=P.|last3=O’Brien|first3=P.|publisher=Pearson Education.|year=2008|isbn=|edition=7|volume=C|location=New York|pages=}}</ref> In some cases world's fairs became the basis for museums. For instance, The Field Museum in Chicago grew out of the 1893 World's Columbian Exposition.<ref>{{cite web|title=History|url=https://www.fieldmuseum.org/about/history|website=The Field Museum|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref>
[[Museums Association]], the first professional membership organization for those working in the museum field, was established in London in 1889. In 1901, they developed [[Museums Journal]], the first publication devoted entirely to the theory and practice of museums, and soon after other magazines appeared, like Museumskunde in Germany (1905) and the [[American Alliance of Museums|American Association of Museum’s]] Museum Work in the United States (1919). With the creation of the [[International Council of Museums]] (ICOM) in 1946, the study of museums gained increasing momentum and exposure, though at the time most of the scholarly focus was on operational museology, or museum practice.<ref>{{Cite book|title=For Instruction and Recreation: A Centenary History of the Museums Association|last=Lewis|first=G.|publisher=Quiller Press.|year=1989|isbn=1-870948-37-8|location=London|pages=}}</ref> <ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=Critical Museology: A Manifesto.|last=Shelton|first=A.|publisher=Museum Worlds|year=2013|isbn=|volume=5 |issue=1|location=|pages=8.}}</ref>
Beginning in the 1950s, new forms of museology were emerging as a way to revitalize the educational role of museums.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Van Mensch|first=Peter|date=1995|title=Magpies on Mount Helicon. Museum and Community|url=|journal=ICOFOM Study Series|volume=25|pages=133–138|via=}}</ref> One attempt to re-envision museums’ role was the concept of [[Ecomuseum]]s, first proposed publicly at ICOM’s 9th International Conference in France (1971).<ref>{{Cite book|title=Panamanian Museums and Historical Memory.|last=Sánchez Laws|first=Ana Luisa|publisher=Berghahn Books.|year=2011|isbn=|location=New York|pages=}}</ref> [[Ecomuseum]]s proliferated in Europe – and still exist around the world today – challenging traditional museums and dominant museum narratives, with an explicit focus on community control and the development of both heritage and sustainability. In 1988, Robert Lumley’s book The Museum Time Machine “expressed the growing disquiet about traditional museological presuppositions and operations”.<ref name=":2" /> The following year, Peter Vergo published his critically acclaimed edited collection The New Museology (1989/1997), a work that aimed to challenge the traditional or “old” field of museology, and was named one of the Paperbacks of the Year by [[The Sunday Times]] in Britain.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The New Museology|last=Vergo|first=Peter|publisher=University of Chicago Press Books|year=1989|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Around the same time, Ivan Karp co-organized two ground-breaking conferences at the Smithsonian, Exhibiting Cultures (1988) and Museums and Communities (1990), that soon resulted in highly influential volumes of the same names that redefined museums studies.<ref name=ExhibitingCultures>{{cite book|last1=Karp|first1=Ivan|last2=Lavine|first2=Steven D.|title=Exhibiting Cultures: The Poetics and Politics of Museum Display|date=1991|publisher=Smithsonian Press|location=Washington DC}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Karp|first1=Ivan|last2=Kreamer|first2=Christine Mullen|last3=Lavine|first3=Steven|title=Museums and Communities: The Politics of Public Culture|date=1992|publisher=Smithsonian|location=Washington DC}}</ref> Scholars who are engaged in various “new” museological practices sometimes disagree about when this trend “officially” began, what exactly it encompasses, and whether or not it is an ongoing field of study. However, the common thread of New Museology is that it has always involved some form of “radical reassessment of the roles of museums within society”.<ref name=":1" />
Critical theorists like [[Michel Foucault]], [[Walter Benjamin]], and [[Benedict Anderson]] also had a profound influence on late 20th and early 21st century museology. As other disciplines began to be critically reassessed – often adding the term “critical” to their new titles (i.e. [[critical race theory]]) – a discourse of critical museology also emerged, intensifying around the turn of the 21st century. It arose from a similar critical discourse as New Museology and shares many of its features – so much so that many scholars disagree about the extent to which you can distinguish one from the other. In other words, while some scholars say that New Museology was a watershed moment in the late 20th century and critical museology is a related but separate movement in the early 21st century, others argue that New Museology is an ongoing field of study that has many manifestations and names, one of which is critical museology <ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Stam|first=D.|date=1983|title=The Informed Muse: The Implications of 'The New Museology' for Museum Practice|url=|journal=Museum Management and Curatorship|volume=12|pages=267–283|via=}}</ref><ref name=":2" />
The latest movements in museology tend to focus on museums being [[Interdisciplinarity|interdisciplinary]], multi-vocal, accessible, and open to criticism. While these critical discourses dominate contemporary museology, there are many different kinds of museums that exist today, some of which are engaged in new and innovative practices, and others that are more traditional and less critical.<ref name=":3" />
== Operational museology == Operational museology refers to the day-to-day operations of a museum, including its organizational and regulatory structures, institutional policies and protocols (procedural, ethical, etc.), collections management (including [[Conservation-restoration of cultural heritage|conservation and restoration]]), and its [[Exhibit design|exhibitions]] and programs.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":0" /> While there has been much scholarship around operational museology over the last 30 years, some scholars argue that it has lacked sustained analysis.<ref name=":2" />
==Critical museology==
=== Overview of the field === Critical museology has emerged as a key discourse in contemporary museology. It is a broad field of study that engages critically with museums, calling into question the foundation assumptions of the field.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Shelton|first1=Anthony|title=Critical Museology: A Manifesto|journal=Museum Worlds|date=2013|volume=1|issue=1|pages=7–23}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite book|title=Curatorial Dreams: Critics Imagine Exhibition|last=Lehrer|first=Erica|last2=Butler|first2=Shelley Ruth|publisher=McGill-Queen’s University Press|year=2016|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> This demonstrates critical museology’s close connection to New Museology, which also challenges foundational assumptions in museology. Critical museology may also extend beyond the traditional [[museum]] to include [[Cultural center|cultural centres]], [[Historic site|heritage sites]], [[memorial]]s, [[Art museum|art galleries]], and so on.<ref name=":5">{{Cite book|title=The Birth of the Museum: History, Theory, Politics|last=Bennett|first=Tony|publisher=Routledge|year=1995|isbn=|location=London|pages=}}</ref><ref name=ExhibitingCultures /><ref>{{Cite book|title=Hybrid Cultures: Strategies for Entering and Leaving Modernity|last=Canclini|first=Nestor Garcia|publisher=University of Minnesota Press|year=1995|isbn=|location=Minneapolis|pages=}}</ref>
=== Development of the field === Given that museums are historically linked to [[colonialism]], [[imperialism]], and European [[missionary]] work, they have a morally and politically problematic past. While some of the objects museums hold were purchased – though not always fairly and often to the exclusive benefit of the collector – a large proportion of museum collections were taken as spoils of war, or otherwise removed without the consent of the people or community that owned them.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Greenblatt|first=Steven|date=1991|title=Resonance and Wonder|url=|journal=Exhibiting Cultures: Poetics and Politics of Museum Display|volume=|pages=44|via=}}</ref> Museums, along with their collections – and collectors – played a key role in establishing and reiterating the dominance of colonial Europe and narratives of cultural superiority. Critical museology was developed through questioning the foundational assumptions of museum studies and museums, including their history, architecture, display, programming, and the provenance of their objects.<ref name=":5" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Duncan|first=Carol|date=|title=Art Museums and the Ritual of Citizenship|url=|journal=Exhibiting Cultures. Smithsonian Institution|volume=|pages=88–103|via=}}</ref> Recent work has also analyzed exhibition design to show how the diverse media combined in exhibitions communicate and shape visitors' interpretations and values.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kratz|first1=Corinne A.|title=The Ones That Are Wanted: Communication and the Politics of Representation in a Photographic Exhibition|date=2002|publisher=University of California|location=Berkeley}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kratz|first1=Corinne|title=Rhetorics of Value: Constituting Worth and Meaning through Cultural Display|journal=Visual Anthropology|date=2011|volume=27|issue=1|pages=21–48}}</ref> While [[anthropologist]]s and the field of [[anthropology]] were actively engaged in problematic collecting practices for two centuries, anthropologists have also been central to the emergence of critical museology in the late 20th and early 21st centuries.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Lorente|first=J. P.|date=2015|title=From the White Cube to a Critical Museography: The Development of Interrogative, Plural and Subjective Museum Discourses|url=|journal=From Museum Critique to the Critical Museum|publisher=Routledge|volume=|pages=80|via=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Karp|first1=Ivan|last2=Kratz|first2=Corinne|editor1-last=Silverman|editor1-first=Raymond|title=The Interrogative Museum|journal=Museum as Process: Translating Local and Global Knowledges|date=2015|publisher=Routledge}}</ref> This has included reconstructing and analyzing those collection histories and the relationships that grew around them, as in the Pitt Rivers Museum's "Relational Museum" project.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gosden|first1=Chris|title=The Relational Museum|url=http://www.materialworldblog.com/2009/01/the-relational-museum/|website=Material World|accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref> They have also led interdisciplinary working groups that developed new approaches to globalizing processes in critical museology, as foregrounded in Museum Frictions, a third innovative volume co-edited by Ivan Karp.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Karp|first1=Ivan|last2=Kratz|first2=Corinne|last3=Szwaja|first3=Lynn|last4=Ybarra-Frausto|first4=Tomas, et al|title=Museum Frictions: Public Cultures/ Global Transformations|date=2006|publisher=Duke University Press|location=Durham}}</ref> Additionally, anthropologists have spearheaded recent methodological and pedagogical developments in critical museology including “curatorial dreaming”, curating labs like the [http://hennessy.iat.sfu.ca/mcl/ Making Culture Lab] at [[Simon Fraser University]], the [http://capsl.cerev.ca/ Curating and Public Scholarship Lab] at [[Concordia University]], and the [http://www.carmah.berlin/ Centre for Anthropological Research on Museums and Heritage] (CARMAH) in Berlin, as well as courses like the [https://www.concordia.ca/artsci/academics/summer/critical-museology.html International Field School in Critical Museology].<ref name=":4" /> In other contexts, historians have been at the forefront of interventions in critical museology.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Witz|first1=Leslie|last2=Minkley|first2=Gary|last3=Rassool|first3=Ciraj|title=Unsettled History: Making South African Public Pasts|date=2017|publisher=University of Michigan Press}}</ref>
=== Decolonizing and indigenizing museums === In North America, Australia, and New Zealand in particular, critical museology attempts to address the problematic colonial pasts of museums through the decolonization and Indigenization of museums.
Once viewed as the formal process of handing over the instruments of government, decolonizing is now recognized – particularly in Canada – as a long-term process that involves dismantling the bureaucratic, cultural, linguistic, and psychological legacies of colonial power <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Huygens|first=Ingrid|date=2011|title=Developing a Decolonisation Practice for Settler Colonisers: A Case Study from Aotearoa New Zealand|url=|journal=Settler Colonial Studies|volume=1 |issue=2|pages=53–81|via=}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=http://www.trc.ca/websites/trcinstitution/File/2015/Honouring_the_Truth_Reconciling_for_the_Future_July_23_2015.pdf|title=Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada Final Report – Executive Summary|last=|first=|date=2015|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> While there is no agreed upon end-goal of decolonization, the process of decolonizing the museum is aimed at “assist[ing] communities in their efforts to address the legacies of historical unresolved grief by speaking the hard truths of colonialism and thereby creating spaces for healing and understanding”.<ref name=":6" />
Collaboration, consultation, and [[Repatriation (cultural heritage)|repatriation]] are key components of decolonizing museums. Australian museums have been leaders in developing repatriation processes, consultation, and collaboration with Indigenous communities, beginning in the late 1980s.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Griffin|first1=Des|last2=Paroissien, eds.|first2=Leon|title=Understanding Museums: Australian museums and museology|url=http://nma.gov.au/research/understanding-museums/_lib/pdf/Understanding-Museums_Indigenous_people_and_museums.pdf|website=National Museum Australia|publisher=National Museum Australia|accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref> Projects involving collaboration and consultation with source communities have taken many forms, ranging from developing traveling exhibits, revising collection catalogues, to establishing community cultural centers and working with photographic collections together.<ref>{{cite web|title=Luo Visual History Project|url=http://web.prm.ox.ac.uk/Luo/luo/page/home/|website=Pitt Rivers Museum|accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Silverman, ed.|first1=Raymond|title=Museum as Process: Translating Local and Global Knowledges|date=2015|publisher=Routledge|location=NY}}</ref> In Canada, collaboration and consultation were first formally suggested by the 1994 Task Force Report on Museums and First Peoples, and are now seen by many museums as being an essential practice for any institution that holds collections belonging to [[Indigenous peoples]].<ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=http://museums.in1touch.org/uploaded/web/docs/Task_Force_Report_1994.pdf|title=Task Force Report on Museums and First People|last=Assembly of First Nations & Canadian Museums Association|first=|date=1994|website=museums.in1touch.org/uploaded/web/docs/Task_Force_Report_1994.pdf|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In North America, and around the world, some of the objects in those collections – particularly sacred objects or human remains – have been [[Repatriation (cultural heritage)|repatriated]] or returned to their communities of origin. [[Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act|The Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act (1990)]] formalized the process of [[Repatriation (cultural heritage)|repatriating]] Indigenous cultural objects in the United States. While Canada does not have a formal policy around repatriation, many museums have their own internal policies and many objects have been returned to Indigenous communities that way. Though repatriation policies are typically well intended, the process has often been complicated by institutional, community, and government politics, and have had varying degrees of success.
A newer concept, the I[[Indigenization|ndigenization]] of museums, moves away from focusing exclusively on collaborative methods and towards employing Indigenous people to work in positions of power within museums as a means of opening up the museum to sustained Indigenous influences, and restructuring the museum to reflect Indigenous approaches to knowledge sharing. Examples of indigenizing museum practice include [[Art Gallery of Ontario]]'s 2016 appointing of [[Wanda Nanibush]] as the Curator of Canadian and Indigenous Art,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/visualarts/2016/07/22/wanda-nanibush-named-agos-first-curator-of-indigenous-art.html|title=Wanda Nanibush Named AGO’s First Curator of Indigenous Art|last=Whyte|first=Murray|date=2016|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> Wood Land School’s takeover of the SBC Gallery of Contemporary Art in Montreal,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://docs.wixstatic.com/ugd/2b2fa6_8f2b4b9eece24189920c7ab3031744f0.pdf|title=Inside a Year-Long Experiment in Indigenous Institutional Critique.|last=Hampton|first=John|date=2017|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> the appointment of Aboriginal curators at the South Australia Museum, the Australian Museum, the National Museum of Australia, and the Museum of Contemporary Art Australia,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Daley|first1=Paul|title=An Indigenous curator for Indigenous artefacts: South Australia breaks new ground|url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/postcolonial-blog/2016/sep/03/an-indigenous-curator-for-indigenous-artefacts-south-australia-breaks-new-ground|accessdate=16 January 2018|publisher=The Guardian|date=2 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Djon Mundine|url=https://www.boomerangfestival.com.au/schedule/detail.aspx?ArtistID=113|website=Boomerang Festival|accessdate=16 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Laura McBride|url=https://australianmuseum.net.au/staff/laura-mcbride|website=Australian Museum|accessdate=16 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=TWO FIRST NATIONS CURATORS FROM MCA AUSTRALIA CHOSEN FOR VENICE BIENNALE|url=https://www.mca.com.au/press/2017/05/04/two-first-nations-curators-mca-australia-chosen-venice-biennale/|website=Museum of Contemporary Art Australia|accessdate=16 January 2018}}</ref> and the creation of the Reciprocal Research Network, which is an interactive online resource co-developed by the [[Musqueam Indian Band]], the [[Sto:lo Nation|Sto:lo Nation Tribal Council]], the U’mista Cultural Centre, and the [[Museum of Anthropology at UBC|Museum of Anthropology]] at [[University of British Columbia|UBC]], to facilitate collaborative research and knowledge exchange between communities, scholars, and cultural institutions in Canada and internationally.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rrncommunity.org/pages/about|title=Reciprocal Research Network|last=|first=|date=2014|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
While there is no linear trajectory of decolonizing/Indigenizing work in museums, major milestones in Canada include the [[Indians of Canada Pavilion]] at [[Expo 67]]’; The [[Lubicon Lake Indian Nation|Lubicon Cree]]’s boycott of [[Colonialism and the Olympic Games#Claims of cultural theft and erasure at the 1988 Winter Olympics in Calgary.2C AB|The Spirit Sings]], a [[Shell Oil Company|Shell]] sponsored exhibition at the [[Glenbow Museum]] [[Glenbow Museum|i]]<nowiki/>n 1[[Glenbow Museum|9]]8[[Glenbow Museum|8]], and the resulting Task Force Report on Museums and First Peoples in 1994;<ref name=":8" /> and [[Truth and Reconciliation Commission (Canada)|The Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada]]’[[Truth and Reconciliation Commission (Canada)|s]] [[Truth and Reconciliation Commission (Canada)|2]]0[[Truth and Reconciliation Commission (Canada)|1]]5 final report, with Calls to Action that specifically address museums and archives.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Igloliorte|first=Heather|date=2012|title="No History of Colonialism": Decolonizing Practices in Indigenous Arts|url=|journal=Decolonize Me|publisher=ABC Art Books Canada.|volume=|pages=19–27|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Decolonizing Museology (Lecture)|last=Igloliorte|first=Heather|publisher=|year=2017|isbn=|location=International Field School in Critical Museology Lecture, Concordia University.|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Alsford|first=Stephen|last2=MacDonald|first2=George|date=1995|title=Canadian Museums and the Representation of Culture in a Multicultural Nation|url=|journal=Cultural Dynamics|volume=7 |issue=1|pages=15–36|via=}}</ref><ref name=":7" />
== New methodologies ==
=== Museum interventions === Interventions in museums were [[Art intervention|first employed by artists]] like [[Marcel Duchamp]], who were looking to challenge both established elite art traditions and the expectations of museum visitors. By the late 20th century, interventions had become a methodology used not only by artists, but also by other groups – including activists, museum visitors, and even museums themselves – as a way to democratize exhibitions, challenge dominant narratives, problematize the provenance of museum objects, and so on.
==== Artist interventions ==== A central aspect of [[Institutional Critique]], some artist’s interventions have been co-organized or commissioned by museums themselves – like [[Fred Wilson (artist)|Fred Wilson]]’s Mining the Museum (1992) at the [[Maryland Historical Society]], [[Michael Nicoll Yahgulanaas|Michael Nicholl Yahgulanaas]]’ Meddling in the Museum (2007) at UBC’s [[Museum of Anthropology at UBC|Museum of Anthropology]], or the Artists' Interventions at the Pitt Rivers Museum in Oxford<ref>{{cite web|title=Artists' Interventions|url=https://www.prm.ox.ac.uk/artists|website=Pitt Rivers museum|accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref> – while others have been done without explicit permission, like [[Andrea Fraser]]’s Museum Highlights (1989) at the [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wilson|first=Fred|last2=Halle|first2=Howard|date=1993|title=Mining the Museum|jstor=25007622|journal=Grand Street|issue=44|pages=151–172|doi=10.2307/25007622}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bmoreart.com/2017/05/how-mining-the-museum-changed-the-art-world.html|title=How Mining the Museum Changed the Art World – BmoreArt {{!}} Baltimore Contemporary Art|website=www.bmoreart.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Fred Wilson: Objects and Installations 1979-2000.|last=Berger|first=Maurice|publisher=|year=2001|isbn=|location=Baltimore, Maryland: Center for Art and Visual Culture.|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Levell|first=N.|date=2013|title=Site-Specificity and Dislocation: Michael Nicholl Yahgulanaas and His Haida Manga Meddling|url=|journal=Journal of Material Culture|volume=18 |issue=2|pages=93–116.|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://faculty.washington.edu/kbunn/Manga.pdf|title=Michael Nicholl Yahgulanaas: Meddling in the Museum.|last=UBC MOA|first=|date=2007|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Martin|first=Richard|date=2014|title=Andrea Fraser – Museum Highlights: A Gallery Talk (1989)|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/fraser-museum-highlights-a-gallery-talk-t13715|journal=Tate: Art & Artists.|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2010/3/30/fraser-art-institutional/|title=Spotlight: Andrea Fraser {{!}} Arts {{!}} The Harvard Crimson|website=www.thecrimson.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref>
One of the best known artist interventions in a museum is [[James Luna]]’s ''Artifact Piece'', which was first performed at the San Diego Museum of Man in 1987, and then again at ''The Decade Show'' in New York in 1990. Luna, a [[Luiseño]] artist, lay almost naked in a display case filled with artifacts in order to challenge representations of Indigenous peoples in museums and the narratives that accompanied those representations, which suggested that Indigenous people and cultures were dead. The objects in the case included Luna's favorite books and music, his divorce papers, his university degree, photos, and other mementos, alongside labels describing the scars on his body and how he had acquired them.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/arts-culture/james-luna-30545878/|title=James Luna. Smithsonian Magazine.|last=K. R.|first=Fletcher|date=2008|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> The work was critically acclaimed for its challenge of conventional narratives of Indigeneity and Indigenous experience. A few years later, two artists – Guillermo Gómez-Peña and Coco Fusco – developed a traveling performance art piece called [[Couple in The Cage: Two Undiscovered Amerindians Visit the West|The ''Couple in the Cage: Two Amerindiens Visit the West'']] that reflected on the treatment and representation of Indigenous peoples in colonial contexts, and was performed in many different spaces, including [[Covent Gardens]], the [[Walker Art Center]], the Smithsonian's [[National Museum of Natural History]], the [[Australian Museum|Australia Museum]], and the [[Field Museum of Natural History|Field Museum]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mannheim|first=Bruce|last2=Behar|first2=Ruth|date=1995|title=In Dialogue: The Couple in the Cage: A Guatinaui Odessy|url=|journal=Visual Anthropology Review|volume=11 |issue=1|pages=118–127|via=}}</ref>
==== Activist interventions ==== While there is overlap between artist and activist interventions, specific activist groups such as the [[Guerrilla Girls]] have long been creating exhibitions and public advertisements – through the use of billboards, stickers, posters, and projections – to critique power dynamics related to sexism, racism, and class privilege in museums.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.guerrillagirls.com|title=Guerrilla Girls|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
There is also a tradition of activist interventions being used as responses to the censorship of exhibited artworks. In 1989, after the [[Corcoran Gallery of Art]] cancelled [[Corcoran Gallery of Art#Mapplethorpe scandal|''The Perfect Moment'']], an exhibition of Robert Mapplethorpe’s explicit photography, protesters projected Mapplethorpe’s photos on the exterior of the museum.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/01/arts/crowd-at-corcoran-protests-mapplethorpe-cancellation.html|title=Crowd at Corcoran Protests Mapplethorpe Cancellation|last=Gamarekian|first=Barbara|date=1989-07-01|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-11-14|last2=Times|first2=Special to The New York|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Similar protests occurred when [[David Wojnarowicz]]’s film [[David Wojnarowicz#.22A Fire in My Belly.22 controversy|''A Fire in My Belly'']] was removed from the [[National Portrait Gallery (United States)#Hide.2FSeek controversy|''Hide/Seek: Difference and Desire in American Portraiture'']] exhibit at the [[National Portrait Gallery (United States)|National Portrait Gallery]] in 2010.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/12/09/AR2010120905895.html|title='Fire' man: Wojnarowicz, censored by Smithsonian, sounded an alarm in dire times|last=Kennicott|first=Philip|date=2010-12-10|access-date=2017-11-14|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
==== Museum hack ==== Museum interventions have also become increasingly popular through companies such as Museum Hack, which offers unconventional tours of large museums such as the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] or the [[American Museum of Natural History]]. These tours depart from traditional methods of museum interpretation by using humor and technology to appeal to younger generations or non-typical museum audiences. Museum Hack functions with permission from the institutions in which they work, rather than providing unsolicited tours.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://museumhack.com/|title=Museum Hack - Team Building Activities & Museum Tours|website=Museum Hack|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref>
==== Internal institutional interventions ====
While most interventions are directed at museums from outside sources, museums also engage interventions as a way of performing self-critique. For example, in 2015 [[Museum of Modern Art|MoMA]] mounted a meta-intervention exhibit called ''Messing with MoMA: Critical Interventions at the Museum of Modern Art 1939 – Now''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://post.at.moma.org/content_items/804-messing-with-moma-critical-interventions-at-the-museum-of-modern-art-1939-now|title=Messing with MoMA: Critical Interventions at the Museum of Modern Art, 1939–Now|last=Tobias|first=Jennifer|date=May 26, 2016|website=post.at.moma.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-11-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.moma.org/interactives/exhibitions/2015/messingwithmoma/|title=Moma.org {{!}} Interactives {{!}} Exhibitions {{!}} Messing With MoMA|website=www.moma.org|access-date=2017-11-22}}</ref> In a similar way, ethnographic exhibitions have been incorporating contemporary art as a way to disrupt conventional expectations and narratives.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Geismar|first1=Haidy|title=he Art of Anthropology: Questioning Contemporary Art in Ethnographic Display|journal=The International Handbooks of Museum Studies|date=2015|volume=2|issue=10|pages=183–210}}</ref>
=== Curatorial dreaming === Curatorial Dreaming was originally developed as a challenge to museum critics, who are typically not expected to provide practical solutions to the issues they identify in the exhibits they critique, to develop their own imagined exhibitions. It is intended as “an alternative mode of critical, intellectual practice – a form of ‘theorizing in the concrete’”.<ref name=":4" />
=== Curating workshops, courses and labs === {{external links|section|date=January 2018}} Over the last three decades there has been a proliferation of curating workshops, courses, and labs that engage with New Museology and critical museology in museum spaces, in universities, and elsewhere.<ref>{{cite web|title=Art Radar|url=http://artradarjournal.com/2014/08/22/14-curatorial-training-programmes-in-north-america/|website=14 Curatorial Training Programmes|accessdate=7 January 2018}}</ref> For instance, the [http://www.bard.edu/ccs/visit/about-ccs-bard/mission/ Bard Center for Curatorial Studies] in New York was founded in 1990 and began offering a graduate program in 1994.<ref>{{cite web|title=About CSS|url=http://www.bard.edu/ccs/visit/about-ccs-bard/mission/|website=CSS Bard|accessdate=7 January 2018}}</ref> In Germany, the [http://www.carmah.berlin/ Centre for Anthropological Research on Museums and Heritage] is engaging with the social, cultural, and political issues facing contemporary museums.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.carmah.berlin/our-centre/|title=CARMAH – Our Centre|website=www.carmah.berlin|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-22}}</ref> In Canada, two of the most innovative curating labs are the [http://hennessy.iat.sfu.ca/mcl/ Making Culture Lab] at [[Simon Fraser University]] in Vancouver and the [http://capsl.cerev.ca/ Curating and Public Scholarship Lab] at [[Concordia University]] in Montreal, which offered its inaugural [https://www.concordia.ca/artsci/academics/summer/critical-museology.html International Field School in Critical Museology] in May 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://hennessy.iat.sfu.ca/mcl/|title=Making Culture Lab|website=hennessy.iat.sfu.ca|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://capsl.cerev.ca/|title=Curating and Public Scholarship Lab|website=Curating and Public Scholarship Lab|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.concordia.ca/artsci/academics/summer/critical-museology.html|title=Curatorial Dreams|website=www.concordia.ca|access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref> The [https://www.uwc.ac.za/Faculties/ART/History/Pages/APMHS.aspx African Programme in Museum and Heritage Studies] in Cape Town includes a curatorial module within a comprehensive diploma and M.A. program that engages critically with museum and heritage studies, the leading program on the continent.<ref>{{cite web|title=African Programme in Museum and Heritage Studies|url=https://www.uwc.ac.za/Faculties/ART/History/Pages/APMHS.aspx|website=UWC APMHS|accessdate=7 January 2018}}</ref>

TATE: Art & Artists. Retrieved from: <nowiki>http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/fraser-museum-highlights-a-gallery-talk-t13715</nowiki> * McCall, V. & Gray, C. (2014). Museums and the ‘New Museology’: Theory, Practice and Organizational Change. Museum Management and Curatorship 29(1): 19-35. * Messing with MoMA (2015). Retrieved from: <nowiki>https://www.moma.org/interactives/exhibitions/2015/messingwithmoma/</nowiki> * Mollica, J. (2017). Send Me SFMOMA. Retrieved from: <nowiki>https://www.nps.gov/nagpra/</nowiki> * Reciprocal Research Network (2014). Retrieved from: <nowiki>https://www.rrncommunity.org/pages/about</nowiki> * Ryzik, M. (2017). Text for Happiness. Or Sadness. Get Art Back. The New York Times. Retrieved from: <nowiki>https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/14/arts/design/sfmoma-texting-emojis-art.html</nowiki> * Sánchez Laws, A. L. Retrieved from: <nowiki>http://post.at.moma.org/content_items/804-messing-with-moma-critical-interventions-at-the-museum-of-modern-art-1939-now</nowiki> * Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada Final Report – Executive Summary (2015). Retrieved from <nowiki>http://www.trc.ca/websites/trcinstitution/File/2015/Honouring_the_Truth_Reconciling_for_the_Future_July_23_2015.pdf</nowiki> * UBC MOA (2007). page.title: New Labour, New Life for Britain

revision.comment: Bot: [[User:KolbertBot|HTTP→HTTPS]] (v485)
revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''New Labour, New Life For Britain''''' was a political [[manifesto]] published in 1996 by the [[Labour Party (UK)|British Labour Party]]. The party had recently rebranded itself as [[New Labour]] under [[Tony Blair]]. The manifesto set out the party's new "Third Way" centrist approach to policy, with subsequent success at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997 general election]].<ref name="manifesto">[http://www.politicsresources.net/area/uk/man/lab97.htm new Labour because Britain deserves better] - Political Science Resources. Access date: 10 July 2012.</ref>
The 1997 general election produced the biggest Labour majority in the history of the party's existence. They won 418 seats, with a majority of 179.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/vote_2005/basics/4393323.stm 1997: ''Labour landslide ends Tory rule''] - [[BBC News]]. Last updated: 15 April 2005, Access date: 10 July 2012.</ref> They delivered on the main aims of the manifesto including introducing a [[minimum wage]], increasing [[National Health Service]] (NHS) spending and reducing class sizes in schools.
The [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservatives]]' rule was over after eighteen years; under the leadership of [[John Major]] they suffered their worst defeat since the 1906 general election, losing 178 seats, including the unseating of seven Conservative Cabinet Ministers and the loss of all their Scottish and Welsh representation; becoming the official opposition with 165 seats. This election was the start of a Labour government following an 18-year spell in opposition and continued with another landslide victory in 2001 and a third consecutive victory in 2005. In 2010, they became the official opposition with 258 seats. The new Leader of the Labour Party, [[Ed Miliband]], completely abandoned the New Labour branding in 2010 after being elected, moving the party's political stance slightly further to the left.<ref>[https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/ed-miliband-ditches-new-labour-110754 ''Ed Miliband ditches New Labour''] - [[Daily Mirror|The Mirror]]. Published: 15 February 2012, Access date: 10 July 2012.</ref> He resigned as leader in 2015, and was succeeded by [[Jeremy Corbyn]] at the September 2015 Labour Leadership election, who has further distanced the party from brand.
==Pledge card== During the 1997 campaign, a pledge card with five specific pledges was issued and detailed in the manifesto too. The pledges were:<ref name="manifesto" /> * Cut class sizes to 30 or under for 5, 6 and 7-year-olds by using money from the assisted places scheme. * Fast-track punishment for persistent young offenders by halving the time from arrest to sentencing. * Cut [[National Health Service|NHS]] waiting lists by treating an extra 100,000 patients as a first step by releasing £100,000,000 saved from NHS red tape. * Get 250,000 under-25s off benefits and into work by using money from a windfall levy on the privatised utilities. * No rise in income tax rates, cut [[VAT]] on heating to 5% and inflation and interest rates as low as possible.
==See also== * ''[[Our Society, Your Life]]'' * [[Individual Learning Account]]s * [[Freedom of Information Act 2000]] * [[Human Rights Act 1998]] * [[National Minimum Wage Act 1998]] * [[Regional development agency|Regional development agencies]] * [[Devolution#United Kingdom|Devolution]] * [[UK Trident programme]] (retaining) * [[Windfall Tax (United Kingdom)]] * [[Landmines#Efforts to ban anti-personnel mines|Total ban on the use of landmines]]
==References== <references />
{{New Labour}}
[[Category:New Labour]] [[Category:Political history of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Political manifestos]] [[Category:1996 in politics]] [[Category:1996 in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Party programs]] [[Category:1996 documents]]

page.title: Peri-Urban Areas Health Board v Munarin

revision.text:
In '''''Peri-Urban Areas Health Board v Munarin''''', an important case in South African law, the issue concerned the liability of the employer of an independent contractor for damages arising from the death of a third party who was injured in consequence of the dangerous operations being performed by the contractor. In the course of his judgment, in terms of which the employer's liability was confirmed, Holmes JA said,
Negligence is the breach of a duty of care. In general, the law allows me to mind my own business. Thus, if I happen to see someone else's child about to drown in a pool, ordinarily I do not owe a legal duty to anyone to try to save it. But sometimes the law requires me to be my brother's keeper. This happens, for example, when the circumstances are such that I owe him a duty of care; and I am negligent if I breach it. I owe him such a duty if a ''diligens paterfamilias'', that notional epitome of reasonable prudence, in the position in which I am in [''sic''], would—
(a) foresee the possibility of harm occurring to him; and
(b) take steps to guard against its occurrence.
Foreseeability of harm to a person, whether he be a specific individual or one of a category, is usually not a difficult question, but when ought I to guard against it? It depends upon the circumstances in each particular case, and it is neither necessary nor desirable to attempt a formulation which would cover all cases. For the purposes of the present case it is sufficient to say, by way of general approach, that if I launch a potentially dangerous undertaking involving the foreseeable possibility of harm to another, the circumstances may be such that I cannot reasonably shrug my shoulders in unconcern but have certain responsibilities in the matter—the duty of care.373E-H.
== See also == * [[South African agency law]] == References == * ''Peri-Urban Areas Health Board v Munarin'' 1965 (3) SA 367 (A). == Notes == {{Reflist}} [[Category:South African case law]] [[Category:1965 in case law]] [[Category:1965 in South African law]] {{SouthAfrica-case-law-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Canon Law}} {{Anglican realignment}} A '''personal ordinariate''', sometimes called a "personal ordinariate for former Anglicans"<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=7BJ_MAEACAAJ&dq Peter John Elliott, ''A Little Catechism on the Personal Ordinariates for Former Anglicans'' (James Goold House Publications, 2012] {{ISBN|978-1-92115413-3}})</ref><ref>"The erection of Personal Ordinariates for former Anglicans" - [https://books.google.com/books?id=5JBSw4m9azYC&pg=PT106 Stephen E.
